head.title: Simple and Versatile Non-Fullerene Acceptor Based on Benzothiadiazole and Rhodanine for Organic Solar Cells | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Simple and Versatile Non-Fullerene Acceptor Based on Benzothiadiazole and Rhodanine for Organic Solar Cells

Most non-fullerene acceptors (NFAs) are designed in a complex planar molecular conformation containing fused aromatic rings in high-efficiency organic solar cells (OSCs). To obtain the final molecules, however, numerous synthetic steps are necessary. In this work, a novel simple-structured NFA containing alkoxy-substituted benzothiadiazole and a rhodanine end group (BTDT2R) is designed and synthesized. We also investigate the photovoltaic properties of BTDT2R-based OSCs employing representative polymer donors (wide band gap and high-crystalline P3HT, medium band gap and semicrystalline PPDT2FBT, and narrow band gap and low-crystalline PTB7-Th) to compare the performance capabilities of fullerene acceptor-based OSCs, which are well matched with various polymer donors. OSCs based on P3HT:BTDT2R, PPDT2FBT:BTDT2R, and PTB7-Th:BTDT2R achieved efficiency as high as 5.09, 6.90, and 8.19%, respectively. Importantly, photoactive films incorporating different forms of optical and molecular ordering characteristics exhibit favorable morphologies by means of solvent vapor annealing. This work suggests that the new n-type organic semiconductor developed here is highly promising as a universal NFA that can be paired with various polymer donors with different optical and crystalline properties.

div.p: Most non-fullerene acceptors (NFAs) are designed in a complex planar molecular conformation containing fused aromatic rings in high-efficiency organic solar cells (OSCs). To obtain the final molecules, however, numerous synthetic steps are necessary. In this work, a novel simple-structured NFA containing alkoxy-substituted benzothiadiazole and a rhodanine end group (BTDT2R) is designed and synthesized. We also investigate the photovoltaic properties of BTDT2R-based OSCs employing representative polymer donors (wide band gap and high-crystalline P3HT, medium band gap and semicrystalline PPDT2FBT, and narrow band gap and low-crystalline PTB7-Th) to compare the performance capabilities of fullerene acceptor-based OSCs, which are well matched with various polymer donors. OSCs based on P3HT:BTDT2R, PPDT2FBT:BTDT2R, and PTB7-Th:BTDT2R achieved efficiency as high as 5.09, 6.90, and 8.19%, respectively. Importantly, photoactive films incorporating different forms of optical and molecular ordering characteristics exhibit favorable morphologies by means of solvent vapor annealing. This work suggests that the new n-type organic semiconductor developed here is highly promising as a universal NFA that can be paired with various polymer donors with different optical and crystalline properties.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Non-fullerene acceptors (NFAs) have emerged as alternative materials for fullerene-based acceptors because they can strongly absorb light, readily control the energy levels, sufficiently reduce the energy loss, and dramatically enhance the morphological stability.
(1−9)
With rapid development of NFAs, the maximum power conversion efficiency (PCE) of NFA-based organic solar cells (OSCs) has already overtook their fullerene-based systems, achieving over 15%.
(10,11)

Among the categorized NFA structures, A–D–A structure is one of the most successful architecture for NFA-based OSCs. In here, D is an electron-donating building block composed of highly fused aromatic cores such as indacenodithiophene (IDT) or indacenodithieno[3,2-
b
]thiophene (IDTT) derivatives. A is an electron-deficient end group, such as 2-(3-oxo-2,3-dihydro-1
H
-inden-1-ylidene)malononitrile or rhodanine. When introducing bulky substituent groups on the center carbon atoms of the D structure, intermolecular aggregation can be moderated by leading optimum phase-separation domains. At the same time, two A parts are suggested to form efficient π–π stacking, which can enhance electron-transporting ability between neighbor molecules.
(12,13)
However, to synthesize final IDT or IDTT-based NFAs such as ITIC and IDIC, over nine complicated synthesis steps are necessary.
(14−18,57,58)
Thus, synthesizing these fused and complex materials including the multisynthetic and purification steps is expensive and time-consuming and results in a low yield. It is necessary to optimize the synthetic routes by reducing the synthesis steps or by designing a novel simple-structured NFA. In relation to this, recently, the simplest NFA, T2-ORH, was reported. It consists of a bithiophene core and is linked with rhodanine end groups. In addition, its PCE exceeds 9%.
(19)

On the basis of the abovementioned considerations, we also attempted to realize the successful design, synthesis, and characterization of a novel NFA composed of a bithiophene core linked with benzothiadiazole (BT) at the center and ethyl-substituted rhodanine at the ends (BTDT2R). The BT units have been widely used for the design of n-type structures because of its strong electron-withdrawing and promising optoelectronic properties, which are considered as an excellent prospect for NFA structures.
(20−24)
Meanwhile, a recently published NFA, T2-ORH, has shown limited solubility [only soluble in chloroform (CF)] and a strong aggregating tendency. Therefore, it is difficult to fabricate photoactive layers, and the process is not suitable for a highly crystalline polymer donor such as poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT). A novel BTDT2R NFA with an alkoxy functional group on the BT unit exhibits good solubility in commonly used solvents and mixes well with polymer donors with different degrees of crystallinity. To prove these effects, we investigate the photovoltaic properties based on typical polymer donors exhibiting different band gaps and crystalline properties with BTDT2R in OSCs.

In general, most fullerene derivatives such as [6,6]-phenyl-C61/C71-butyric acid methyl ester (PC
61
BM/PC
71
BM) are a good match with diverse polymer donors having different optical and molecular packing properties. However, high-efficiency NFA-based OSCs utilizing various polymer donors having different properties are rarely reported.
(25−27)
It is hard to find universal NFAs which are well communicated with various polymer donors having different band gaps, energy levels, molecular packing, and morphological properties.
(28−30)
Thus, it is highly meaningful to develop universal NFAs that can operate efficiently with multiple polymer donors. Recently, Yang’s group reported a new ladder-type acceptor of m-MeIC with IDTT as a central core unit and methylated thiophene-fused ending groups (Me-CPTCN) as end-capping units, allowing the creation of highly efficient OSCs with three different band gap polymer donors. However, the chemical structures and molecular orientation properties of the three polymer donors are similar and thus can be distinguished in the results of this study.
(31,51,52)

Herein, we investigated the photovoltaic properties based on the new simple-structured BTDT2R acceptor-based OSCs combined with representative polymer donors of P3HT (wide band gap and high-crystalline, P1), poly[(2,5-bis(2-hexyldecyloxy)phenylene)-
alt
-(5,6-difluoro-4,7-di(thiophen-2-yl)benzo[
c
]-[1,2,5]thiadiazole)] (PPDT2FBT) (medium band gap and semicrystalline, P2), and poly[4,8-bis(5-(2-ethylhexyl)thiophen-2-yl)benzo[1,2-
b
;4,5-
b
′]dithiophene-2,6-diyl-
alt
-(4-(2-ethylhexyl)-3-fluorothieno[3,4-
b
]thiophene)-2-carboxylate-2-6-diyl)]] (PTB7-Th) (narrow band gap and low-crystalline, P3) (
Figure
1
a). These polymer donors show completely different features, not only in the energy band gap but also in the molecular orientation. The OSCs based on P3HT, PPDT2FBT, and PTB7-Th exhibited remarkable PCEs of 5.09, 6.90, and 8.19%, respectively. The improved open-circuit voltage (
V
OC
), short-circuit current (
J
SC
), and fill factor (FF) of the PTB7-Th-based system contributed to achieving the best PCE, and it is accompanied by reduced energy loss and enhanced complementary absorption between the donor and the acceptor. These results indicate that even for multiple polymer donors with different properties, rational designs of new NFAs can lead to further improvements in OSC performance capabilities while also shining light on the choice of different NFAs for high-performance OSCs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The new unfused simple NFA, BTDT2R, was synthesized according to
Scheme 1
, and donor polymers are displayed in
Figure
1
a. First, alkoxy substituted BT (1) was brominated to obtain compound 2. Then, compound 2 was reacted with boronic acid thiophene as a Suzuki reaction to afford compound 3. Next, two formyl groups were reacted with 2-ethylrhodanine for approaching the final NFA, BTDT2R. The synthetic methods and analysis are explained in Scheme S1 and
Supporting Information
. BTDT2R composed of alkoxy solubilizing groups is well soluble in organic solvents, such as methylene chloride, CF, and chlorobenzene. The thermal properties of BTDT2R were estimated via thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (see
Figure S1
). The
T
d
(5%-decomposition temperature) of BTDT2R was confirmed to be 284 °C under a N
2
atmosphere, and it has good thermal stability. In the DSC curves of BTDT2R, the distinct melting or glass transition peaks did not appear from 50 to 250 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min
–1
. Through density functional theory calculations, the energy-optimized molecular geometry of BTDT2R was determined, as shown in
Figure S2
, which indicates that the range of the dihedral angle between the benzene ring and the thiophene unit (A1 or A2) is approximately 34°–48°, whereas the calculated dihedral angle (A3) between the thiophene and rhodanine units in the BTDT2R backbone is 3.26°. The electron clouds are distributed over all molecules at the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) state, whereas the lowest molecular orbital (LUMO) is concentrated on the electron-accepting rhodanine unit. It is suggested that this large electron-accepting area located on the edge of the whole structure will improve the electron transfer between molecules.
(32)
The moderate dihedral angles of BTDT2R are evidence of a nonplanar geometry, which is advantage for a favorable morphology of photoactive films in NFA-based OSCs.
(33)
Scheme 1. Synthetic Routes of BTDT2R as a NFA

The normalized light absorption spectra of BTDT2R in a CF solution and in thin films are shown in
Figure
1
b. The compound exhibits strong absorption from 300 to 600 nm, covering a short wavelength region. From the solution to film forms, the red shift of 50 nm is mainly ascribed to intermolecular π–π stacking. Meanwhile, the BTDT2R film exhibits an absorption onset of 658 nm (
E
g
opt
= 1.88 eV). From the cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement, we can investigate the electrochemical properties of BTDT2R. As shown in
Figure S3
, the HOMO and LUMO energy levels were estimated as −5.67 and −3.80 eV, respectively, and the band gap is 1.81 eV, which is summarized in
Table
1
. The introduction of an alkoxy side group into the BT core unit results in a favorable energy level to obtain a high
V
OC
value of the corresponding devices as well as appropriate suitable solubility. The absorption spectra in the film states of P3HT (P1), PPD2FBT (P2), PTB7-Th (P3), and BTDT2R are displayed in
Figure
1
c. The P1, P2, and P3 films exhibited absorption onsets at 650, 700, and 800 nm, respectively, with corresponding
E
g
opt
values of 1.91, 1.77, and 1.58 eV.
(59)
Therefore, representative polymer donors with different band gaps were chosen to assess the photovoltaic properties of the new BTDT2R NFA-based OSCs in this study.
Table 1. Optical Absorption Properties and Molecular Energy Levels of BTDT2R

div.div:
To investigate the photovoltaic properties of this novel BTDT2R NFA, inverted OSCs with the device structure of indium tin oxide (ITO)/ZnO nanoparticles (NPs)/PEIE/polymer donor:BTDT2R/MoO
X
/Ag were fabricated. An energy band diagram of the device from the vacuum energy levels is shown in
Figure
2
a. After a systematic device optimization process (
Tables S1–S10
,
Figures S4–S13
), with CF as the main solvent, the polymer donor:BTDT2R weight ratio was optimized to 1.0:2.0, and solvent vapor annealing (SVA) using dichloromethane (DCM) for 15 s was selected as the best condition to achieve the highest efficiency. In
Figure
2
b and
Table
2
, the optimum current density–voltage (
J
–
V
) curves and the corresponding photovoltaic parameters of the OSCs are presented.

characteristics and (c) EQE curves of P1, P2, and P3:BTSR2R-based OSCs without and with SVA under AM 1.5G illumination with a light intensity of 100 mW cm
–2
.

div.div:
The device based on P1:BTDT2R achieved a PCE of 5.09% with a
V
OC
of 0.81 V, a
J
SC
of 9.42 mA cm
–2
, and an FF of 67%; P2:BTDT2R achieved a PCE of 6.90% with a
V
OC
of 1.07 V, a
J
SC
of 11.23 mA cm
–2
, and an FF of 57%. Finally, P3:BTDT2R achieved a PCE of 8.19%, a
V
OC
of 1.06 V, a
J
SC
of 13.52 mA cm
–2
, and an FF of 57%. Furthermore, we estimated the energy loss according to
E
loss
=
E
g
opt
–
eV
OC
. The P3:BTDT2R-based device (0.53 eV) exhibits the lowest energy loss when compared with that of OSC based on P1:BTDT2R (0.94 eV) and P2:BTDT2R (0.65 eV). This is mainly due to high charge-carrier mobilities, low series resistance, and optimized LUMO energy-level offset in the P3-based device, which are beneficial for obtaining higher
V
OC
with reduced
E
loss
in the related NFA systems.
(54−56)
As a result, the highest efficiency of the PTB7-Th (P3):BTDT2R device, up to 8.19%, was achieved under AM 1.5G one-sun illumination because of the high
V
OC
and
J
SC
values attributed to the reduced energy loss and improved complementary light absorption between P3 and BTDT2R. In comparison with the P3-based device, OSCs based on P1 and P2 exhibited lower PCEs of 5.09 and 6.90%, respectively, but those values also indicate impressive performance compared to results in the literature.
(34−38)

To achieve higher efficiency in single-junction OSCs, ternary-blend strategies have been suggested as alternative protocols. From this perspective, we also fabricated ternary-blend OSCs by combining P1, P3, and the newly synthesized acceptor BTDT2R using a 1:2 weight ratio of the polymer donors to the BTDT2R acceptor. The device architecture of the ternary-blend OSCs is ITO/ZnO NPs/PEIE/P3HT:PTB7-Th:BTDT2R/MoO
X
/Ag. The best
J
–
V
and external quantum efficiency (EQE) curves of ternary-blend OSCs with/without SVA are shown in
Figure S14
, and the corresponding photovoltaic parameters are listed in
Table S11
. Unfortunately, the efficiency of the ternary-blend OSCs showed poor photovoltaic properties compared to that of binary OSCs. The best PCE of the ternary-blend system is 4.49% with a
V
OC
up to 0.81 V, a
J
SC
of 9.19 mA cm
–2
, and an FF of 61% for the P1:P3:BTDT2R (1.5:0.5:4.0) ternary-blend film. We believe that the morphological incompatibility in terms of molecular orientation and phase separation between P1 and P3 results in deteriorated photovoltaic properties in ternary-blend OSCs.

NFA-based OSCs employing the P1, P2, or P3 donor exhibit enhanced photovoltaic properties after SVA treatment, especially in terms of
J
SC
and FF. These outcomes originate from the improved light absorption, charge mobilities, molecular ordering, and morphological properties, as discussed below. All of the SVA-processed OSCs show highly feasible photovoltaic properties, reflecting the universality of the BTDT2R NFA with polymer donors and indicating different band gaps and crystalline characteristics. The EQE spectra of the optimal OSCs were also obtained (
Figure
2
c). The spectra of all devices cover a multiplex range following the donor absorption spectrum. In comparison with the devices based on P1 and P2, the P3-based OSC exhibited a higher photocurrent response from 700 to 800 nm mainly due to the strong absorbance of P3 in the long-wavelength absorption region. Furthermore, it should be noted that all of the devices showed a strong photo response with a maximum value of 70% around 400–600 nm, which is attributed to the novel BTDT2R NFA. The universality of BTDT2R for the three representative polymer donors can be mainly ascribed to its appropriate energy levels with polymer donors to achieve a suitable driving force for exciton dissociation along with strong short-wavelength absorption and high charge-carrier mobility.
(39,40)

div.h3: 2.4. Charge Generation, Transport, and Recombination Study
div.div:
To prove the possibility of a universal form of BTDT2R, the correlation between the carrier recombination and the photovoltaic outcomes of solar systems with the typical polymers was evaluated. Initially, the recombination loss via a function of the light intensity was investigated. The light intensity dependence of the
J
SC
of three OSC devices based on P1, P2, and P3 under various illumination intensities is illustrated in
Figure
3
a. This graph is described as the power law of
J
SC
∝
P
α
, where
P
is the incident light intensity and α is the calculated exponential factor.
(41)
The slope of the SVA-treated OSCs (α values of 0.93, 0.94, and 0.92 for P1:BTDT2R, P2:BTDT2R, and P3:BTDT2R, respectively) is much closer to unity than in as-cast devices (α values of 0.91, 0.89, and 0.90 for P1:BTDT2R, P2:BTDT2R, and P3:BTDT2R, respectively). Importantly, all OSCs with SVA exhibit negligible bimolecular recombinations, leading to enhanced
J
SC
and FF values. Additionally,
Figure
3
b shows the dependence of FF under all light intensities, which suggested that all of the OSCs processed through SVA exhibit an enhanced FF. Specifically, among the three polymer devices, the best FF values were achieved for the P1-based system under all light intensities, suggesting that the most effective carrier transport and extraction happened because of the minor charge recombinations. Furthermore, to understand the effective photoinduced charge generation and transport, the photocurrent density (
J
ph
=
J
L
–
J
D
, where
J
L
is the current density under the illumination and
J
D
is the photocurrent density in the dark) and effective voltage (

=

V
, where
V
is the applied bias voltage and
V
0
is the voltage when

ph
= 0) were obtained (
Figure
3
c). The P1- and P2-based OSCs with SVA displayed a saturated photocurrent (
J
sat
). It can be estimated that this system had zero net-trapped charges, and the generated excitons are dissociated into free carriers.
(42)
In the P3-based OSCs,
J
ph
was almost saturated at a high
V
eff
(≥2 V), suggesting that frequently monomolecular or bimolecular recombination is dominant in this case. Nevertheless, the high
J
ph
value of the P3:BTDT2R OSC would suggest enhanced overall exciton generation. The
J
sat
values of the SVA-processed OSCs based on P1:BTDR2R, P2:BTDT2R, and P3:BTDT2R were found to be 11.04, 12.55, and 16.6 mA cm
–2
, respectively. Under maximal power output and short-circuit conditions, the charge collection probabilities
P
(

,

) were determined by normalizing
J

with
J

(

/

).
(43)
The
P
(
E
,

) values under the
J
SC
conditions for the three SVA-processed OSCs were 85, 89, and 81%, respectively. These results implied that polymer donor:BTDT2R films with SVA exhibit effective exciton generation, separation, and carrier transport to the respective electrodes compared to the as-cast OSCs.
J
–
V
graphs of OSCs with and without the SVA treatment subjected to light with intensities varying from 3.2 to 100 mW cm
–2
are shown in
Figure S15
. For the devices which had undergone the SVA treatment, the photocurrent quickly became saturated at all light intensities, thus demonstrating more efficient charge transfer than in the as-cast OSCs.
(44)

div.p:
Figure 3. Dependence of (a)
J
SC
and (b) FF on the light intensity. (c) Plot of
J
ph
VS
V
eff
for polymer:BTDT2R devices. The PL spectrum of (d) P3HT:BTDT2R film excited at 500 nm, (e) PPDT2FBT:BTDT2R films excited at 650 nm, and (f) PTB7-Th:BTDT2R films excited at 670 nm.

div.div:
In addition, the photoluminescence (PL) was recorded to determine the efficient exciton dissociation and charge transfer behavior in the photoactive layers. The PL spectra of neat P1, P2, and P3 and blended films with and without SVA are shown in
Figure
3
d–f, where the excitation wavelengths of 500, 650, and 670 nm were selected for the selective excitation of the respective polymer donors. The PL spectra showed that the generated excitons were quenched at around 80% by BTDT2R in the neat state, whereas 98% of carriers were quenched at the SVA-treated blend films. This indicates an efficient electron transfer from the polymer donors to the BTDT2R acceptor for the excitons generated in the donor phase. Here, it was also noted that the BTDT2R NFA can be suitably intermixed with polymer donors in the photoactive layer and produce effective photoinduced carrier generation and transport regardless of the polymer donor used.

In addition, the charge-carrier mobility plays an important role in the photovoltaic properties to understand the relationship between charge recombination and exciton dissociation. The electron (μ
e
) and hole mobilities (μ
h
) were measured by the space charge limited current method. In neat film cases, all of μ
h
is similar even with a SVA treatment, whereas the μ
e
value of BTDT2R is significantly improved by more than 1 order of magnitude than before. In comparison with the neat films, the devices based on P1:BTDT2R, P2:BTDT2R, and P3:BTDT2R with SVA showed improvements in both μ
h
and μ
e
by more than 1 order of magnitude (
Tables
2
and
S12
and
Figures S16 and S17
), consistent with the resulting enhanced
J
SC
and FF values. Generally, the degree of crystallinity of photoactive materials is significantly associated with the charge-carrier mobility in OSCs. However, the charge-carrier mobility is also highly dependent on the morphological properties such as the optimized nanoscale interpenetrating donor:acceptor network and molecular orientations in the bulk heterojunction (BHJ) photoactive layer. The P3:BTDT2R-based device exhibits the BHJ morphology with the optimum phase separation to form percolated pathways to the contacts and a preferred face-on orientation than the other BHJ photoactive layers, which will be discussed below (
Figures
4
and
5
). This indicates that the morphological properties are critical to the charge transport in BHJ photoactive films. Furthermore, this result is in good accordance with the trend of a series resistance in the OSCs.

div.p: Figure 4. (a) IP and (b) OOP cut profiles of the GIWAXS images obtained from polymer:BTDT2R. Intensity of π* transitions vs incident angle of (c) P3HT:BTDT2R, (d) PPDT2FBT:BTDT2R, and (e) PTB7-Th:BTDT2R from the NEXAFS TEY mode.

div.div:
Furthermore, the enhanced FF could be explained in terms of the series resistance (
R
S
) and the shunt resistance (
R
SH
) calculated from the dark
J
–
V
curves (
Figure S16c
).
R
S
is related to the intrinsic resistance and morphology of the active layer, whereas
R
SH
is investigated from the leakage current, leading to defect characteristics in the solar devices.
(45−47)
Therefore, smaller
R
S
and larger
R
SH
values were required to fabricate high-performance OSCs. As shown in
Table
2
, the values of
R
SH
in the P1, P2, and P3-based OSCs improved correspondingly from 1.19, 0.48, and 2.63 × 10
4
Ω cm
2
for the as-cast devices to 3.42, 0.82, and 2.84 × 10
4
Ω cm
2
for the devices with SVA. Improved FF values were also obtained in those OSCs with SVA as a result of fewer carrier recombinations, reduced leakage current, and improved diode behavior in the devices.

div.h3: 2.5. Molecular Ordering of the Blended Systems
div.div:
To obtain a deeper understanding of the advantages of the BTDR2R NFA on the molecular packing of polymer donors having different crystalline arrangements, grazing-incidence wide-angle X-ray scattering (GIWAXS) and near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (NEXAFS) analyses were carried out with the optimized device (
Figures
4
,
S18–S21
,
Table S13
).

The neat P1 films showed clear (100) reflections in both the out-of-plane (OOP) and in-plane (IP) directions (lamellar spacings of 15.72 and 16.87 and 15.98 and 16.87 Å for as-cast and SVA films, respectively) as well as a (010) peak along the OOP direction with π–π stacking (
d
-spacings of 3.78 and 3.81 Å correspondingly for the as-cast and SVA films), indicating a predominant face-on orientation (
Figures S18a,e and S19
). The neat P2 composed of well intermixed edge-on and face-on orientations showed (100) and (010) diffraction peaks in both directions. In contrast, the neat P3 preferentially adopts the face-on orientation, showing (100) peaks only in the IP direction with a lamellar spacing of 23.00 Å and pronounced OOP (010) scattering with
d
-spacings of 3.99 and 3.92 Å for the as-cast and SVA films, respectively. The neat BTDT2R film exhibited a lamellar (100) peak in both directions but no distinct diffraction peaks, such as long-range-ordering (
h
00) and π–π stacking (010) peaks, indicating an amorphous nature, as also proved by the DSC data. While the photoactive films with the SVA treatment showed obvious diffraction peaks while retaining the original ordering diffraction behavior of each material, the lamellar (100) peak and the π–π stacking (010) peak in the as-cast photoactive films decreased and merged with each other to create a broader diffraction peak, as shown in
Figure
4
a,b and in
Figure S20
. This indicates that the BTDT2R in the photoactive films with SVA may not interrupt the polymer self-crystalline packing. It arranges proper nanoscale phase separation.

NEXAFS measurements were taken in the total electron yield (TEY) mode to demonstrate the structural orientation of the mixed photoactive materials (
Figures
4
c–e and
S21
).
(48)
The NEXAFS measurements were investigated over an incident X-ray angle (θ) range of 30°–70°, which suggest the average tilt angle (α) of the polymer chains from the dichroism of the C 1s → π* resonant transitions perpendicular to the horizontal of the total structural planes. The average α values of the as-cast photoactive films based on P1, P2, and P3 calculated from the linear fittings are 64.82°, 68.50°, and 59.35°, respectively. Here, α = 0° is correlated as the face-on orientation and α = 90° is attributed from the edge-on orientation. On the other hand, α was changed as 66.35°, 71.78°, and 65.32° for P1-, P2-, and P3-based blend films with SVA, respectively. The dichroic ratios (
R
) were also calculated to compare the packing performance of the blend active layer (
R
= 0.7 edge-on,
R
= 0 random, and
R
= −1 face-on orientation). The
R
values of P1-, P2-, and P3-based photoactive films with SVA are 0.35, 0.50, and 0.33, respectively.

The trend calculated from
R
values is similar to the trend of α, indicating that the polymer donors via SVA had an edge-on orientation with improved molecular ordering on average in the mixed state compared to the as-cast films; this phenomenon is in concurrence with the GIWAXS results. Therefore, BTDT2R initially becomes homogenously dispersed in the polymer matrix, after which it undergoes proper nanoscale phase separation under the influence of SVA. Because BTDT2R shows amorphous-like ordering behavior, it can easily penetrate into the polymer donor matrix. As a result, the BTDT2R in the photoactive layers with SVA forms a favorable morphology without any ordering changes, despite the introduction of polymer donors with diverse crystalline characteristics.

For a closer examination of the structural relationships with the novel BTDT2R NFA, the microstructures of the P1, P2, and P3:BTDT2T blend films were probed with a combination of characterization techniques. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to image the surface and bulk morphologies.
(53)
Figure S22
presents the phase images of the photoactive films. The average grain size of the P1-, P2-, and P3-based films increased, showing self-aggregation and increasing levels of crystalline behaviors with SVA when using DCM for 15 s. Topographic AFM images of the photoactive films are shown in
Figure
5
a–f. The highly crystalline P1-based photoactive films with SVA exhibit slightly increased root-mean-square (rms) roughness values from 0.93 to 0.99 nm. Meanwhile, the images of the semi-crystalline P2 and low-crystalline P3-based photoactive films provide clearer evidence of crystalline enhancement due to SVA. After the SVA treatment using DCM for 15 s, the rms roughness increased from 0.55 to 1.21 nm and from 0.64 to 2.77 nm for the P2:BTDT2R and P3:BTDT2R films, respectively. This phenomenon is also proven by the TEM characterization, as shown in
Figure
5
g–l.

div.p: Figure 5. AFM and TEM images of (a,g) as-cast P1:BTDT2R, (b,h) as-cast P2:BTDT2R, (c,i) as-cast P3:BTDT2R, (d,j) P1:BTDT2R with SVA, (e,k) P2:BTDT2R with SVA, and (f,l) P3:BTDT2R with SVA.

div.div:
No obvious phase separation and well-mixed features are observed in the as-cast P1:BTDT2R film. For the photoactive films treated with SVA, nanoscale phase-separation domains form, indicating a favorable and homogeneous morphology and leading to effective charge transport to the respective electrodes. Similar to the P1-based photoactive films, P2 and P3 blended with BTDR2R also displayed similar behaviors. The P2:BTDT2R blend film without SVA shows an unclear phase-separation image of simply acceptor-rich domains in a polymer matrix. These hinder charge transport and act as charge recombination channels. After the SVA treatment, the photoactive film exhibited a uniform morphology with clear phase separation, an interpenetrating network, and even a nanofibrillar structure. In the as-cast P3-based photoactive film, the nanodomains are scarcely distinguishable by TEM. However, the SVA-based photoactive films exhibited numerous dark dots of aggregated BTDT2R. Nevertheless, the performance of P3:BTDT2R-based OSCs is enhanced after the SVA treatment, indicating that this morphology is favorable for charge transport because the domain size and the length scale are smaller than the exciton diffusion length.
(49,50)
Furthermore, it is important that even polymer donors have a different crystalline nature, and the suitable interaction of the novel BTDT2R acceptor can lead to a favorable nanoscale morphology via the SVA treatment and further improvement in the performance capabilities of OSCs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we designed and synthesized a new simple-structured NFA, BTDT2R, composed of an unfused electron-deficient BT unit and a rhodanine end group. By introducing an alkoxy functional group onto the BT moiety, it can be adequately tuned in terms of the energy level, optical band gap, and solubility. To demonstrate the universality of the novel BTDT2R NFA in OSCs, representative polymer donors, in this case, the wide band gap and highly crystalline P3HT, the medium band gap and semi-crystalline PPDT2FBT, and the narrow band gap and low-crystalline PTB7-Th, were employed as polymer donors. After proper optimization, OSCs with P3HT:BTDT2R, PPDT2FBT:BTDT2R, and PTB7-Th:BTDT2R achieved impressive PCEs of 5.09, 6.90, and 8.19%, respectively. As a result, the PTB7-Th-based OSC exhibited the highest PCE, which was ascribed to the high
V
OC
and
J
SC
values, consistent with the reduced energy loss and improved complementary light absorption between the donor and the acceptor. Despite the fact that all of the polymer donors have different molecular orientations, the photoactive films form favorable and homogeneous morphologies with proper nanoscale phase separation. These results indicate that the simple design and synthesis of a novel NFA can play a role in realizing promising candidates and shine some light on the use of alternative polymer donors for high-performance OSCs.

div.div:
The detailed synthesis, procedure, and analysis of the BTDT2R acceptor are given in the
Supporting Information
.

div.h3: 4.2. Fabrication and Measurement of the OSCs
div.div:
In this study, the OSCs were fabricated with the structure ITO/ZnO NPs/PEIE/photoactive layer/MoO
X
/Ag. The procedure for cleaning the ITO substrates included sonication and rinsing in deionized water, acetone, and isopropyl alcohol for at least 15 min. The ITO-coated glass substrates were dried in oven for 5 h. After the treatment of the ITO-coated glass substrates by ultraviolet–ozone for 15 min, a thin layer of ZnO NPs (ca. 20 nm) was spin-coated onto ITO and then annealed at 100 °C for 10 min in air. The PEIE solution was spin-coated on top of the ZnO NPs. After that, the ZnO NPs/PEIE-coated substrates were transferred to the nitrogen-filled glovebox. For deposition of the photoactive layer, the blend solutions of donor:acceptor (1.0:2.0 w/w) dissolved in CF were spin-cast on top of the PEIE layer. Then, the substrates were placed in a glass Petri dish containing 150 μL of CH
2
Cl
2
for SVA for 15 s. Finally, a 10 nm-thick MoO
X
film and 100 nm Ag were deposited successively to complete the inverted device structure. The photoactive area of the OSCs is 0.09 cm
2
by using the aperture. Solar cell efficiencies were characterized under simulated 100 mW/cm
2
AM 1.5G irradiation from a Xe arc lamp with an AM 1.5 global filter. Simulator irradiance was characterized using a calibrated spectrometer, and the illumination intensity was set using an NREL-certified silicon diode with an integrated KG1 optical filter. The EQE was measured by underfilling the device area using a reflective microscope objective to focus the light output from a 100 W Xe lamp outfitted with a monochromator and an optical chopper; the photocurrent was measured using a lock-in amplifier, and the absolute photon flux was determined using a calibrated silicon photodiode. All device fabrication procedures and measurements were carried out in air at room temperature. Ternary-blend OSCs are also fabricated with the same process routes of binary devices.

A review. Org. solar cells (OSCs) have been dominated by donor:acceptor blends based on fullerene acceptors for over 2 decades. This situation has changed recently, with non-fullerene (NF) OSCs developing very quickly. The power conversion efficiencies of NF OSCs have now reached a value of over 13%, which is higher than the best fullerene-based OSCs. NF acceptors show great tunability in absorption spectra and electron energy levels, providing a wide range of new opportunities. The coexistence of low voltage losses and high current generation indicates that new regimes of device physics and photophysics are reached in these systems. This Review highlights these opportunities made possible by NF acceptors, and also discuss the challenges facing the development of NF OSCs for practical applications.

The field of non-fullerene org. solar cells has experienced rapid development during the past few years, mainly driven by the development of novel non-fullerene acceptors and matching donor semiconductors. However, org. solar cell material development has progressed via a trial-and-error approach with limited understanding of the materials' structure-property relationships and the underlying device physics of non-fullerene devices. In addn., the availability of hundreds of donor and acceptor semiconductors creates an extremely large pool of possible donor-acceptor combinations, which poses a daunting challenge for rational material screening and matching. This Review describes several important conceptual aspects of the emerging non-fullerene devices by highlighting key contributions that provided fundamental insights regarding rational material design, donor-acceptor pair matching, blend morphol. control and the reduced voltage losses in non-fullerene org. solar cells. We also discuss the key challenges that need to be addressed to develop more-efficient non-fullerene org. solar cells.

A review. Fullerenes have formed an integral part of high performance org. solar cells over the last 20 years, however their inherent limitations in terms of synthetic flexibility, cost and stability have acted as a motivation to develop replacements; the so-called non-fullerene electron acceptors. A rapid evolution of such materials has taken place over the last few years, yielding a no. of promising candidates that can exceed the device performance of fullerenes and provide opportunities to improve upon the stability and processability of org. solar cells. In this review we explore the structure-property relationships of a library of non-fullerene acceptors, highlighting the important chem. modifications that have led to progress in the field and provide an outlook for future innovations in electron acceptors for use in org. photovoltaics.

Org. solar cells (OSCs) have gained attention of the scientific community from the last decade and are now considered as one of the most important source for low-cost power prodn. The recent rapid progress in non-fullerene acceptors in BHJ indicates that they have potential to compete with fullerene-based BHJ OSCs. The present review addressed the systematic comparison among various acceptors (diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP), benzothiadiazole (BTD) and perylenediimide (PDI) based acceptors) in order to design and improve the performance of small mols. based non-fullerene acceptors. This review focuses on the performance of small mol. non-fullerene acceptors based on DPP, BTD and PDI for OSCs with respect to the change in mol. structures, energy levels, and PCE. A systematic comparison on the effect of mol. architecture, side chains on their performance is provided with the intention of evaluating the challenge to make highly efficient acceptors for the next generation org. photovoltaics.

The development of org. electron acceptor materials is one of the key factors for realizing high performance org. solar cells. Compared to traditional fullerene acceptor materials, non-fullerene electron acceptors have attracted much attention due to their better optoelectronic tunabilities and lower cost as well as higher stability. Non-fullerene org. solar cells have recently experienced a rapid increase with power conversion efficiency of single-junction devices over 14% and a bit higher than 15% for tandem solar cells. In this review, two types of promising small-mol. electron acceptors are discussed: perylene diimide based acceptors and acceptor(A)-donor(D)-acceptor(A) fused-ring electron acceptors, focusing on the effects of structural modification on absorption, energy levels, aggregation and performances.We strongly believe that further development of non-fullerene electron acceptors will hold bright future for org. solar cells.

In bulk-heterojunction org. solar cells (BHJ-OSCs), exciton dissocn. and charge transport are highly sensitive to the mol. packing pattern and phase sepn. morphol. in blend films. Efficient photovoltaic small mols. (SMs) typically possess an acceptor-donor-acceptor structure that causes intrinsic anisotropy, limiting the control over mol. packing because of the lack of an effective method for modulating mol. orientation. In this report, the authors design a group of model compds., named DRTB-T-CX (X = 2, 4, 6, and 8), to demonstrate that adjusting the length of the end alkyl chain can be used to modify the mol. orientation. A top-performance power conversion efficiency (PCE) of up to 11.24% is achieved with a DRTB-T-C4/IT-4F-based device, which is the best performance reported for a state-of-the-art nonfullerene SM org. solar cell (NFSM-OSC).

During the past two years, non-fullerene electron acceptors for org. solar cells have attracted considerable attention. Significant progress has been made in that the power conversion efficiency of polymer solar cells based on non-fullerene small mol. acceptors now exceeds 12%, exhibiting many advantages over their fullerene counterparts. One of the greatest strengths for NFAs is their tunability via chem. modulation to fine-tune their absorption, energy level and electronic mobility, which is difficult to achieve with fullerene derivs. This review describes very recent developments of polymer donor:small mol. non-fullerene acceptors in several systems since 2015, including rylene imide, indacenodithiophene and diketopyrrolopyrrole-based small mol. acceptors. Mol. design considerations and structure-property relationships are also discussed.

A review. Heterojunction org. photovoltaics have been the subject of intensive academic interest over the past two decades, and significant com. efforts have been directed towards this area with the vision of developing the next generation of low-cost solar cells. Materials development has played a vital role in the dramatic improvement of org. solar cell performance in recent years, and this is driven primarily by the advancement of p-type semiconductors as donor materials. With the highest performing solar cells today dominated by acceptors based on members of the fullerene family, much less attention has been devoted to other classes of n-type acceptors. In this review, we will provide an overview of the progress in the synthesis, characterization and implementation of the various classes of non-fullerene-based n-type org. acceptors for photovoltaic applications.

Recently, non-fullerene n-type org. semiconductors have attracted significant attention as acceptors in org. photovoltaics (OPVs) due to their great potential to realize high-power conversion efficiencies. The rational design of the central fused ring unit of these acceptor mols. is crucial to maximize device performance. Here, we report a new class of non-fullerene acceptor, Y6, that employs a ladder-type electron-deficient-core-based central fused ring (dithienothiophen[3.2-b]- pyrrolobenzothiadiazole) with a benzothiadiazole (BT) core to fine-tune its absorption and electron affinity. OPVs made from Y6 in conventional and inverted architectures each exhibited a high efficiency of 15.7%, measured in two sep. labs. Inverted device structures were certified at Enli Tech Lab. demonstrated an efficiency of 14.9%. We further obsd. that the Y6-based devices maintain a high efficiency of 13.6% with an active layer thickness of 300 nm. The electron-deficient-core-based fused ring reported in this work opens a new door in the mol. design of high-performance acceptors for OPVs.

To achieve high photovoltaic performance of bulk hetero-junction org. solar cells (OSCs), a range of crit. factors including absorption profiles, energy level alignment, charge carrier mobility and miscibility of donor and acceptor materials should be carefully considered. For electron-donating materials, the deep HOMO (HOMO) energy level that is beneficial for high open-circuit voltage is much appreciated. However, a new issue in charge transfer emerges when matching such a donor with an acceptor that has a shallower HOMO energy level. More to this point, the chem. strategies used to enhance the absorption coeff. of acceptors may lead to increased mol. crystallinity, and thus result in less controllable phase-sepn. of photoactive layer. Therefore, to realize balanced photovoltaic parameters, the donor-acceptor combinations should simultaneously address the absorption spectra, energy levels, and film morphologies. Here, we selected two non-fullerene acceptors, namely BTPT-4F and BTPTT-4F, to match with a wide-bandgap polymer donor P2F-EHp consisting of an imidefunctionalized benzotriazole moiety, as these materials presented complementary absorption and well-matched energy levels. By delicately optimizing the blend film morphol., we demonstrated an unprecedented power conversion efficiency of over 16% for the device based on P2F-EHp:BTPTT-4F, suggesting the great promise of materials matching toward high-performance OSCs.

In this work, a new A-D-A type non-fullerene electron acceptor, DF-PCNC, which possesses an electron-donating (D) core constructed by linking a 2,5-difluorobenzene ring with two cyclopentadithiophene moieties and two electron-accepting (A) end-groups of 2-(3-oxo-2,3-dihydro-1H-cyclopenta[b]naphthalen-1-ylidene)malononitrile (NC), is designed and synthesized. Because of the extension of the π-conjugation system, DF-PCNC shows stronger and more red-shifted absorption peaks while compared to those of its counterpart, DF-PCIC, which has the same D core but smaller A terminals of 2-(3-oxo-2,3-dihydro-1H-inden-1-ylidene)malononitrile (IC). Furthermore, NC groups can enhance the intermol. π-π stacking of DF-PCNC in the condensed state. Thus, when it is blended with a polymer donor, PBDB-T, to fabricate org. solar cells (OSCs), good morphologies of the blended films are achieved through appropriate optimizations: both donor and acceptor form highly cryst. phase-sepn. domains with appropriate nanoscaled sizes, which is beneficial to charge generation and transport in OSCs. As a result, the short-circuit c.d. (JSC) of the PBDB-T:DF-PCNC device is increased by 16% compared with that of the PBDB-T:DF-PCIC one, and a high fill factor (FF) of 72.62% is maintained, leading to a better power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 11.63%, which is the highest value for OSCs based on non-fullerene acceptors adopting decreased fused-ring D cores to date.

A novel strategy involving judiciously fusing one thiophene/thieno[3,2-b]thiophene on only one side of an indacenodithiophene (IDT) unit to extend IDT backbone conjugation was developed, and three A-D-A type non-fullerene small mols. (TPT-2F, TPTT-2F, and TPTTT-2F) were designed and synthesized to investigate the influence of the extent of IDT core conjugation on their photovoltaic properties. Extending the IDT core conjugation could broaden absorption, upshift the LUMO (LUMO) energy level, enhance electron mobility, and increase intermol. π-π stacking. When these three non-fullerene acceptors were applied in org. solar cells (OSCs), simultaneous enhancement of the open-circuit voltage (Voc), short-circuit current (Jsc), and fill factor (FF) was obtained, with the degree of enhancement following the order TPT-2F < TPTT-2F < TPTTT-2F. As a result, the TPTTT-2F based OSCs yielded a high PCE of 12.03%. To the best of our knowledge, the PCE of 12.03% is among the highest values for asym. non-fullerene acceptor based OSCs so far. These results demonstrate that extending the conjugation of the IDT core is an effective approach to design highly efficient asym. non-fullerene acceptors.

A new acceptor-donor-acceptor (A-D-A) type nonfullerene acceptor, 3TT-FIC, which has three fused thieno[3,2-b]thiophene as the central core and difluoro substituted indanone as the end groups, is designed and synthesized. 3TT-FIC exhibits broad and strong absorption with extended onset absorption to 995 nm and a low optical bandgap of 1.25 eV. The binary device based on 3TT-FIC and the polymer PTB7-Th exhibits a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 12.21% with a high short circuit current density ( Jsc) of 25.89 mA cm(-2). To fine-tune the morphology and make full use of the visible region sunlight, phenyl-C71-butyricacid-methyl ester (PC71BM) is used as the third component to fabricate ternary devices. In contrast to the binary devices, the ternary blend organic solar cells show significantly enhanced EQE ranging from 300 to 700 nm and thus an improved Jsc with a high value of 27.73 mA cm(-2). A high PCE with a value of 13.54% is achieved for the ternary devices, which is one of the highest efficiencies in single junction organic solar cells reported to date. The results provide valuable insight for the ternary devices in which the external quantum efficiency (EQE) induced by the third component is evidently observed and directly contributed to the enhancement of the device efficiency.

Charge Generation Pathways in Organic Solar Cells: Assessing the Contribution from the Electron Acceptor
Stoltzfus, Dani M.; Donaghey, Jenny E.; Armin, Ardalan; Shaw, Paul E.; Burn, Paul L.; Meredith, Paul
Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)

Photocurrent generation in org. bulk heterojunction (BHJ) solar cells is most commonly understood as a process which predominantly involves photoexcitation of the lower ionization potential species (donor) followed by electron transfer to the higher electron affinity material (acceptor) [i.e., photoinduced electron transfer (PET), which we term Channel I]. A mirror process also occurs in which photocurrent is generated through photoexcitation of the acceptor followed by hole transfer to the nonexcited donor or photoinduced hole transfer (PHT), which we term Channel II. The role of Channel II photocurrent generation has often been neglected due to overlap of the individual absorption spectra of the donor and acceptor materials that are commonly used. More recently Channel II charge generation has been explored for several reasons. First, many of the new high-efficiency polymeric donors are used as the minority component in bulk heterojunction blends, and therefore, the acceptor absorption is a significant fraction of the total; second, nonfullerene acceptors have been prepd., which through careful design, allow for spectral sepn. from the donor material, facilitating fundamental studies on charge generation. In this article, we review the methodologies for investigating the two charge generation channels. We also discuss the factors that affect charge generation via Channel I and II pathways, including energy levels of the materials involved, exciton diffusion, and other considerations. Finally, we take a comprehensive look at the nonfullerene acceptor literature and discuss what information about Channel I and Channel II can be obtained from the expts. conducted and what other expts. could be undertaken to provide further information about the operational efficiencies of Channels I and II.

The solar cell performance of poly[3-(4-n-octyl)-phenylthiophene] (POPT) and poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) are compared in devices using 4,7-bis(2-(1-(2-ethylhexyl)-4,5-dicyanoimidazol-2-yl)vinyl)benzo[c][1,2,5]-thiadiazole (EV-BT) as the electron acceptor. Despite their decreased light absorption, POPT:EV-BT devices generate higher photocurrents in both bilayer and bulk heterojunction (BHJ) architectures than analogous P3HT:EV-BT devices. Optimized POPT:EV-BT BHJ devices achieve 1.4% av. efficiency, whereas the analogous P3HT devices only reach 1.1%. Morphol. does not account for the large difference in performance as AFM studies of the active layer suggest comparable levels of phase sepn. in the 2 systems. Reverse bias anal. demonstrates that P3HT devices have a higher max. potential than POPT devices, but P3HT devices appear to be more limited by recombination losses under std. operating conditions. A possible explanation for the better performance in POPT devices is that the pendant Ph ring in POPT can twist out-of-plane and increase the sepn. distance with the acceptor mol. A larger donor/acceptor sepn. distance can destabilize the geminate pair and lead to more efficient charge sepn. in POPT:EV-BT devices. The results emphasize the importance of donor/acceptor pair interactions and its effect on charge sepn. processes in polymer solar cells.

Although the field of polymer solar cell has seen much progress in device performance in the past few years, several limitations are holding back its further development. For instance, current high-efficiency (>9.0%) cells are restricted to material combinations that are based on limited donor polymers and only one specific fullerene acceptor. Here we report the achievement of high-performance (efficiencies up to 10.8%, fill factors up to 77%) thick-film polymer solar cells for multiple polymer:fullerene combinations via the formation of a near-ideal polymer:fullerene morphol. that contains highly cryst. yet reasonably small polymer domains. This morphol. is controlled by the temp.-dependent aggregation behavior of the donor polymers and is insensitive to the choice of fullerenes. The uncovered aggregation and design rules yield three high-efficiency (>10%) donor polymers and will allow further synthetic advances and matching of both the polymer and fullerene materials, potentially leading to significantly improved performance and increased design flexibility.

Polymer solar cells are an exciting class of next-generation photovoltaics, because they hold promise for the realization of mech. flexible, lightwt., large-area devices that can be fabricated by room-temp. soln. processing. High power conversion efficiencies of ∼10% have already been reported in tandem polymer solar cells. Here, we report that similar efficiencies are achievable in single-junction devices by reducing the tail state d. below the conduction band of the electron acceptor in a high-performance photoactive layer made from a newly developed semiconducting polymer with a deepened valence energy level. Control over band tailing is realized through changes in the compn. of the active layer and the structure order of the blend, both of which are known to be important factors in cell operation. The approach yields cells with high power conversion efficiencies (∼9.94% certified) and enhanced photovoltage.

Unlike universally applicable fullerene derivs., current nonfullerene electron acceptors are rarely effective with more than one donor polymer in bulk heterojunction (BHJ) solar cells. A novel class of nonfullerene electron acceptors, bis(naphthalene imide)-3,6-diphenyl-trans-anthrazolines (BNIDPAs), that is applicable and yields efficient photovoltaic devices with multiple donor polymers, including a thiazolothiazole-dithienosilole copolymer (PSEHTT) and benzodithiophene copolymers (PBDTT-FTTE and PTB7) is reported. Photovoltaic devices composed of the BNIDPA-butyloctyl (BO) acceptor with PSEHTT, PBDTT-FTTE, and PTB7, resp., have power conversion efficiencies of 3.0%-3.1% with high open-circuit voltages of ≈1.0 V. In contrast, BHJ devices composed of BNIDPA-DT acceptor with larger 2-decyltetradecyl chains and the same donor polymers have substantially reduced bulk electron mobility and reduced photovoltaic efficiencies of 1.3%-1.7%, which highlight the crit. role of the size of alkyl chains appended onto nonfullerene electron acceptors. The present results provide a rare example of nonfullerene electron acceptors that are capable of pairing with multiple donor polymers to achieve efficient BHJ solar cells.

The difference in PCEs between the devices based on J71 and PBDB-T is mainly ascribed to the gap of the open circuit voltage. It should be mentioned that the J71-based device exhibited an energy loss of 0.62 eV, which is significantly lower than the most reported energy loss. For the low band-gap polymer donor PCE-10, the device also showed a relatively high PCE of 8.34%. The different device performances are analyzed in depth from charge transport and collection, to recombination loss mechanism and morphol. of blend films. This work reveals that the new n-type org. semiconductor is very promising as a universal nonfullerene acceptor, pairing with different band-gap polymer donors.

Furthermore, a designed cross-shaped mol. geometry helps in suppressing strong intermol. aggregation in the P3HT : SF(DPPB)4 blend, leading to efficient non-fullerene PSCs. The resultant devices give a max. power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 5.16% with an extremely high open-circuit voltage (Voc) of 1.14 V. In contrast, the devices based on P3HT : PC61BM blends provide a PCE of 3.18% with a Voc of 0.62 V. Finally, we observe that the P3HT : SF(DPPB)4 devices exhibit significantly improved thermal stability from that of the P3HT : PC61BM devices; upon thermal treatment at 150 °C for 3 h, the PCEs of P3HT : SF(DPPB)4 devices remain unchanged, whereas those of the P3HT : PC61BM devices drop drastically to below 1%. The abovementioned results demonstrate that the new design strategy of employing a high-performance non-fullerene acceptor, SF(DPPB)4, is promising for the future practical application of PSCs.

A review. Org. photovoltaics (OPVs) are a promising cost-effective alternative to silicon-based solar cells, and possess low-cost, light-wt., and flexibility advantages. Recently, great advances have been achieved in the development of novel photovoltaic materials and device structures, and the power conversion efficiencies can now reach 7.7%. In this review we summarize the most recent developments in conjugated polymers for high-efficiency OPV devices. We focus on correlations of polymer chem. structures with properties, such as absorption, bandgap, energy levels, mobilities, and photovoltaic performances. This structure-property relationship anal. may guide rational structural design and evaluation of photovoltaic materials.

To achieve efficient non-fullerene org. solar cells, it is important to reduce the voltage loss from the optical bandgap to the open-circuit voltage of the cell. Here we report a highly efficient non-fullerene org. solar cell with a high open-circuit voltage of 1.08 V and a small voltage loss of 0.55 V. The high performance was enabled by a novel wide-bandgap (2.05 eV) donor polymer paired with a narrow-bandgap (1.63 eV) small-mol. acceptor (SMA). Our morphol. characterizations show that both the polymer and the SMA can maintain high crystallinity in the blend film, resulting in cryst. and small domains. As a result, our non-fullerene org. solar cells realize an efficiency of 11.6%, which is the best performance for a non-fullerene org. solar cell with such a small voltage loss.

The current-voltage characteristics of ITO/PEDOT:PSS/OC1C10-PPV:PCBM/Al solar cells were measured in the temp. range 125-320 °K under variable illumination, between 0.03 and 100 mW cm-2 (white light), with the aim of detg. the efficiency-limiting mechanism(s) in these devices, and the temp. and/or illumination range(s) in which these devices demonstrate optimal performance. (ITO: indium tin oxide; PEDOT:PSS: poly(styrene sulfonate)-doped poly(ethylene dioxythiophene); OC1C10-PPV: poly[2-methoxy-5-(3,7-di-Me octyloxy)-1,4-phenylene vinylene]; PCBM: phenyl-C61 butyric acid Me ester.). The short-circuit c.d. and the fill factor grow monotonically with temp. until 320 °K. This is indicative of a thermally activated transport of photogenerated charge carriers, influenced by recombination with shallow traps. A gradual increase of the open-circuit voltage to 0.91 V was obsd. upon cooling the devices down to 125 °K. This fits the picture in which the open-circuit voltage is not limited by the work-function difference of electrode materials used. The overall effect of temp. on solar-cell parameters results in a pos. temp. coeff. of the power conversion efficiency, which is 1.9% at T = 320 K and 100 mW cm-2 (2.5% at 0.7 mW cm-2). The almost-linear variation of the short-circuit c.d. with light intensity confirms that the internal recombination losses are predominantly of monomol. type under short-circuit conditions. The authors present evidence that the efficiency of this type of solar cell is limited by a light-dependent shunt resistance. Also, the electronic transport properties of the absorber materials, e.g., low effective charge-carrier mobility with a strong temp. dependence, limit the photogenerated current due to a high series resistance, therefore the active layer thickness must be kept low, which results in low absorption for this particular composite absorber.

Charge transport and nongeminate recombination are investigated in two soln.-processed small mol. bulk heterojunction solar cells consisting of diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP)-based donor mols., mono-DPP and bis-DPP, blended with [6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM). While the bis-DPP system exhibits a high fill factor (62%) the mono-DPP system suffers from pronounced voltage dependent losses, which limit both the fill factor (46%) and short circuit current. A method to det. the av. charge carrier d., recombination current, and effective carrier lifetime in operating solar cells as a function of applied bias is demonstrated. These results and light intensity measurements of the current-voltage characteristics indicate that the mono-DPP system is severely limited by nongeminate recombination losses. Further anal. reveals that the most significant factor leading to the difference in fill factor is the comparatively poor hole transport properties in the mono-DPP system (2 × 10-5 cm2 V-1 s-1 vs. 34 × 10-5 cm2 V-1 s-1). These results suggest that future design of donor mols. for org. photovoltaics should aim to increase charge carrier mobility thereby enabling faster sweep out of charge carriers before they are lost to nongeminate recombination.

We have systematically explored how plasmonic effects influence the characteristics of polymer photovoltaic devices incorporating a blend of poly(3-hexylthiophene) and [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid Me ester (PCBM). We blended gold nanoparticles into the anodic buffer layer to trigger localized surface plasmon resonance, which enhanced the performance of the polymer photovoltaic devices without dramatically sacrificing their elec. properties. Steady state photoluminescence measurements revealed a significant increase in fluorescence intensity, which we attribute to the increased light absorption in poly(3-hexylthiophene) induced by the localized surface plasmon resonance. As a result, the rate of generation of excitons was enhanced significantly. Furthermore, dynamic photoluminescence measurements revealed that the localized surface plasmon resonance notably reduced the lifetime of photogenerated excitons in the active blend, suggesting that interplay between the surface plasmons and excitons facilitated the charge transfer process. This phenomenon reduced the recombination level of geminate excitons and, thereby, increased the probability of exciton dissocn. Accordingly, both the photocurrents and fill factors of the polymer photovoltaic devices were enhanced significantly. The primary origin of this improved performance was local enhancement of the electromagnetic field surrounding the Au nanoparticles. The power conversion efficiency of the polymer photovoltaic device incorporating the Au nanoparticles improved to 4.24% from a value of 3.57% for the device fabricated without Au nanoparticles.

We present a new and straightforward method to quantify what fraction of charge carriers recombine bimolecularly under operating conditions. This is achieved by accurately measuring the intensity dependence of the photocurrent. Our technique is much more precise than simply measuring the short-circuit current Jsc as a function of intensity I and easily resolves nonlinear behavior that is obscured in conventional measurements. We find that bimol. losses can amt. to tens of percentages under solar illumination while Jsc vs. I seemingly remains linear. This sheds new light on the importance of bimol. recombination at short-circuit conditions. To analyze bimol. recombination losses as a function of light intensity we derive a new anal. model for the photocurrent generated by a solar cell. It includes drift and diffusion of charge carriers as well as bimol. recombination. By fitting this model to the exptl. data of poly(3-hexylthiophene):PCBM solar cells, we find that the bimol. recombination const. is suppressed relative to the Langevin rate.

A review. This paper gives a brief and comprehensive summary on fill factor from a fundamental point of view. The fill factor is an important parameter that dets. the power conversion efficiency of an org. solar cell. There are several factors that can significantly influence fill factor, and these factors interact with each other very intricately. Due to this reason, a deep understanding of fill factor is quite difficult. Based on the three fundamental elements in the solar cell equiv. circuit, namely series resistance, shunt resistance and diode, we review the research progress in understanding on fill factor in org. solar cells. Physics governing the often-obsd. undesirable S-shaped c.d.-voltage curves is also summarized.

Highly efficient ternary polymer solar cells (PSCs) are fabricated from two well-compatible small mol. nonfullerene acceptors (INPIC-4F and MeIC1) and one polymer donor, PBDB-T. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) of the INPIC-4F or MeIC1 based binary PSCs reaches 12.55% and 11.53%. Based on these efficient binary PSCs, a high PCE of 13.73% is achieved in the ternary PSCs with 50 wt% MeIC1 in the acceptors, resulting from the simultaneously improved short circuit current (JSC) of 21.86 mA cm-2, open circuit voltage (VOC) of 0.88 V and fill factor (FF) of 71.39%. The PCE improvement of the ternary PSCs should be mainly attributed to the simultaneously optimized photon harvesting and film morphol. of the ternary active layers. This result may provide more in-depth insight into the material selection criteria for fabricating highly efficient ternary PSCs: (i) the complementary absorption spectra and good compatibility of the used materials; (ii) the complementary photovoltaic parameters of the corresponding two binary PSCs.

The authors report a pentafluorobenzene-based additive (FPE) to control the donor/acceptor (D/A) interfacial morphol. via quadrupolar electrostatic interactions between donor and acceptor polymers in all-polymer solar cells (all-PSCs). The morphol. changes are studied using a combination of at. force microscopy, grazing incidence wide-angle x-ray scattering, and near-edge X-ray absorption fine-structure spectroscopy. Unlike a conventional solvent additive, such as 1,8-diiodooctane, a bicontinuous interpenetrating morphol. without large-scale phase sepn. and an enhanced π-π stacking with face-on orientation are found in the FPE processed blended films. These morphol. changes improve the charge carrier extn. and charge transport between D/A interfaces to achieve an increase in the photovoltaic performance of all-PSCs.

Polymer solar cells based on a poly(3-hexylthiophene)/[6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric-acid Me ester (P3HT/PCBM) composite are one of state-of-the-art polymer photovoltaic devices in terms of performance. A 2-step controlled solvent vapor annealing (C-SVA) process was used to achieve an optimized morphol. for the photoactive layer with an appropriate size of PCBM aggregates and improved crystallinity of P3HT. As revealed by bright-field TEM, and AFM, XRD and UV-visible spectroscopy, PCBM forms aggregates with sizes of ∼30 nm during the 1st step C-SVA in THF vapor. The 2nd step treatment using CS2 vapor on one hand decreases the size of these PCBM aggregates to ∼20 nm, but increases the crystallinity of P3HT. Polymer solar cells employing a thus-treated composite film gave a power conversion efficiency ≤3.9%, in contrast to 3.2% for the thermally-annealed device under the same conditions. This result shows the importance of a precisely controlled morphol. of the photoactive layer in device performance.

A bicontinuous network formed spontaneously upon film prepn. is highly desirable for bulk-heterojunction (BHJ) org. solar cells (OSCs). Many donor-acceptor (D-A) type conjugated polymers can self-assemble into polymer fibrils in the solid state and such fibril-assembly can construct the morphol. framework by forming a network structure, inducing the formation of ideal BHJ morphol. Our recent works have revealed that the fibril network strategy (FNS) can control the blend morphol. in fullerene, non-fullerene and ternary OSCs. It has been shown that the formation of fibril network can optimize phase sepn. scale and ensure efficient exciton dissocn. and charge carriers transport, thus leading to impressive power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) and high fill factor (FF) values. We believe that FNS will provide a promising approach for the optimization of active layer morphol. and the improvement of photovoltaic performance, and further promote the commercialization of OSCs.

The authors report the design and synthesis of a novel electron acceptor based on a bulky seven-ring fused core (indacenodithioeno[3,2-b]thiophene, IT), end-capped with 2-(3-oxo-2,3-dihydroinden-1-ylidene)malononitrile (INCN) groups, and with four 4-hexylphenyl groups substituted on it. Each INCN has one carbonyl and two cyano groups, and these electron-withdrawing groups can downshift LUMO levels. The rigid hexylphenyl groups can restrict phase sepn. in blend films. Polymer solar cells based on these mols. blended with PTB7-TH exhibit solar conversion efficiencies up to 6.8% without post-treatment, higher than for control devices blased on PTB7-TH/[6,6]PCBM blends.

Semi-crystalline photovoltaic polymers with efficiency exceeding 9% in a ∼300 nm thick conventional single-cell device
Nguyen, T. L.; Choi, H.; Ko, S.-J.; Uddin, M. A.; Walker, B.; Yum, S.; Jeong, J.-E.; Yun, M. H.; Shin, T. J.; Hwang, S.; Kim, J. Y.; Woo, H. Y.

We report a series of semi-cryst., low band gap (LBG) polymers and demonstrate the fabrication of highly efficient polymer solar cells (PSCs) in a thick single-cell architecture. The devices achieve a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of over 7% without any post-treatment (annealing, solvent additive, etc.) and outstanding long-term thermal stability for 200 h at 130 °C. These excellent characteristics are closely related to the mol. structures where intra- and/or intermol. noncovalent hydrogen bonds and dipole-dipole interactions assure strong interchain interactions without losing soln. processability. The semi-cryst. polymers form a well-distributed nano-fibrillar networked morphol. with PC70BM with balanced hole and electron mobilities (a h/e mobility ratio of 1-2) and tight interchain packing (a π-π stacking distance of 3.57-3.59 Å) in the blend films. Furthermore, the device optimization with a processing additive and methanol treatment improves efficiencies up to 9.39% in a ∼300 nm thick conventional single-cell device structure. The thick active layer in the PPDT2FBT:PC70BM device attenuates incident light almost completely without damage in the fill factor (0.71-0.73), showing a high short-circuit c.d. of 15.7-16.3 mA cm-2. Notably, PPDT2FBT showed negligible changes in the carrier mobility even at ∼1 μm film thickness.

A review. Org. solar cells (OSCs) have been dominated by donor:acceptor blends based on fullerene acceptors for over 2 decades. This situation has changed recently, with non-fullerene (NF) OSCs developing very quickly. The power conversion efficiencies of NF OSCs have now reached a value of over 13%, which is higher than the best fullerene-based OSCs. NF acceptors show great tunability in absorption spectra and electron energy levels, providing a wide range of new opportunities. The coexistence of low voltage losses and high current generation indicates that new regimes of device physics and photophysics are reached in these systems. This Review highlights these opportunities made possible by NF acceptors, and also discuss the challenges facing the development of NF OSCs for practical applications.

The field of non-fullerene org. solar cells has experienced rapid development during the past few years, mainly driven by the development of novel non-fullerene acceptors and matching donor semiconductors. However, org. solar cell material development has progressed via a trial-and-error approach with limited understanding of the materials' structure-property relationships and the underlying device physics of non-fullerene devices. In addn., the availability of hundreds of donor and acceptor semiconductors creates an extremely large pool of possible donor-acceptor combinations, which poses a daunting challenge for rational material screening and matching. This Review describes several important conceptual aspects of the emerging non-fullerene devices by highlighting key contributions that provided fundamental insights regarding rational material design, donor-acceptor pair matching, blend morphol. control and the reduced voltage losses in non-fullerene org. solar cells. We also discuss the key challenges that need to be addressed to develop more-efficient non-fullerene org. solar cells.

A review. Fullerenes have formed an integral part of high performance org. solar cells over the last 20 years, however their inherent limitations in terms of synthetic flexibility, cost and stability have acted as a motivation to develop replacements; the so-called non-fullerene electron acceptors. A rapid evolution of such materials has taken place over the last few years, yielding a no. of promising candidates that can exceed the device performance of fullerenes and provide opportunities to improve upon the stability and processability of org. solar cells. In this review we explore the structure-property relationships of a library of non-fullerene acceptors, highlighting the important chem. modifications that have led to progress in the field and provide an outlook for future innovations in electron acceptors for use in org. photovoltaics.

Org. solar cells (OSCs) have gained attention of the scientific community from the last decade and are now considered as one of the most important source for low-cost power prodn. The recent rapid progress in non-fullerene acceptors in BHJ indicates that they have potential to compete with fullerene-based BHJ OSCs. The present review addressed the systematic comparison among various acceptors (diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP), benzothiadiazole (BTD) and perylenediimide (PDI) based acceptors) in order to design and improve the performance of small mols. based non-fullerene acceptors. This review focuses on the performance of small mol. non-fullerene acceptors based on DPP, BTD and PDI for OSCs with respect to the change in mol. structures, energy levels, and PCE. A systematic comparison on the effect of mol. architecture, side chains on their performance is provided with the intention of evaluating the challenge to make highly efficient acceptors for the next generation org. photovoltaics.

The development of org. electron acceptor materials is one of the key factors for realizing high performance org. solar cells. Compared to traditional fullerene acceptor materials, non-fullerene electron acceptors have attracted much attention due to their better optoelectronic tunabilities and lower cost as well as higher stability. Non-fullerene org. solar cells have recently experienced a rapid increase with power conversion efficiency of single-junction devices over 14% and a bit higher than 15% for tandem solar cells. In this review, two types of promising small-mol. electron acceptors are discussed: perylene diimide based acceptors and acceptor(A)-donor(D)-acceptor(A) fused-ring electron acceptors, focusing on the effects of structural modification on absorption, energy levels, aggregation and performances.We strongly believe that further development of non-fullerene electron acceptors will hold bright future for org. solar cells.

In bulk-heterojunction org. solar cells (BHJ-OSCs), exciton dissocn. and charge transport are highly sensitive to the mol. packing pattern and phase sepn. morphol. in blend films. Efficient photovoltaic small mols. (SMs) typically possess an acceptor-donor-acceptor structure that causes intrinsic anisotropy, limiting the control over mol. packing because of the lack of an effective method for modulating mol. orientation. In this report, the authors design a group of model compds., named DRTB-T-CX (X = 2, 4, 6, and 8), to demonstrate that adjusting the length of the end alkyl chain can be used to modify the mol. orientation. A top-performance power conversion efficiency (PCE) of up to 11.24% is achieved with a DRTB-T-C4/IT-4F-based device, which is the best performance reported for a state-of-the-art nonfullerene SM org. solar cell (NFSM-OSC).

During the past two years, non-fullerene electron acceptors for org. solar cells have attracted considerable attention. Significant progress has been made in that the power conversion efficiency of polymer solar cells based on non-fullerene small mol. acceptors now exceeds 12%, exhibiting many advantages over their fullerene counterparts. One of the greatest strengths for NFAs is their tunability via chem. modulation to fine-tune their absorption, energy level and electronic mobility, which is difficult to achieve with fullerene derivs. This review describes very recent developments of polymer donor:small mol. non-fullerene acceptors in several systems since 2015, including rylene imide, indacenodithiophene and diketopyrrolopyrrole-based small mol. acceptors. Mol. design considerations and structure-property relationships are also discussed.

A review. Heterojunction org. photovoltaics have been the subject of intensive academic interest over the past two decades, and significant com. efforts have been directed towards this area with the vision of developing the next generation of low-cost solar cells. Materials development has played a vital role in the dramatic improvement of org. solar cell performance in recent years, and this is driven primarily by the advancement of p-type semiconductors as donor materials. With the highest performing solar cells today dominated by acceptors based on members of the fullerene family, much less attention has been devoted to other classes of n-type acceptors. In this review, we will provide an overview of the progress in the synthesis, characterization and implementation of the various classes of non-fullerene-based n-type org. acceptors for photovoltaic applications.

Recently, non-fullerene n-type org. semiconductors have attracted significant attention as acceptors in org. photovoltaics (OPVs) due to their great potential to realize high-power conversion efficiencies. The rational design of the central fused ring unit of these acceptor mols. is crucial to maximize device performance. Here, we report a new class of non-fullerene acceptor, Y6, that employs a ladder-type electron-deficient-core-based central fused ring (dithienothiophen[3.2-b]- pyrrolobenzothiadiazole) with a benzothiadiazole (BT) core to fine-tune its absorption and electron affinity. OPVs made from Y6 in conventional and inverted architectures each exhibited a high efficiency of 15.7%, measured in two sep. labs. Inverted device structures were certified at Enli Tech Lab. demonstrated an efficiency of 14.9%. We further obsd. that the Y6-based devices maintain a high efficiency of 13.6% with an active layer thickness of 300 nm. The electron-deficient-core-based fused ring reported in this work opens a new door in the mol. design of high-performance acceptors for OPVs.
